awd_titl_txt: Collaborative Research: Experiential Process Safety Training for Chemical Engineers
awd_abstract_narration:
Process safety is regarded as a critical part of chemical engineering education. However, teaching process safety only in a classroom setting makes it difficult for students to grasp contextual factors that impact decisions they may make in a real-world scenario. Real life chemical processing environments are difficult to achieve in the classroom and potentially dangerous in an actual facility. Computer-based simulations are beneficial tools for teaching difficult and abstract content due to their ability to immerse the learner within the environment, provide goals, support their learning experience, and provide immediate feedback that allows learning lessons from failure. The proposed approach uses a digital environment that allows students to role-play as chemical plant employees. In this learning environment, students will be given the opportunity to experience first-hand the safety challenges of working in an industrial environment and the difficult decision-making scenarios that often arise. The virtual environment offers conditions that are safe, providing students with real-world experiences without the disastrous consequences of wrong decisions that could occur in real life. 

Working with a professional game design company, the chemical process safety simulations will be implemented in three chemical engineering programs. Following initial consultations, a design document will be produced that specifies details of the simulation's rules and interactions, describing the player's experience and how the player's actions correlate to learning activities. Three appropriate research questions will be investigated regarding student motivation to learn about process safety, changes in ability to make correct safety decisions and cultural differences in safety decision making. Quantitative methods will be applied to determine how the process safety simulation influenced students, in addition, thematic analysis of student reflections on their responses to the process safety decision making prompts within the process safety instrument will be undertaken to further understand the approach students took when examining the scenarios provided.

por.por_cntn:
The NSF IUSE project focused upon the development of two different tools to help better prepare senior chemical engineering students for decisions that they may need to make when working within the chemical industry upon graduation.  The first tool was a survey called the Engineering Process Safety Research Instrument (EPSRI). The EPSRI provides students with different scenarios related to process safety, then asks them to make a decision. Complicating the decision for each scenario is the presence of incentives, such as receiving a bonus at your job, and disincentives, such as a fine that your company may have to pay. After making their decision, the student is asked to rank the incentives and disincentives provided to determine which ones were most important to their decision making process. Results obtained from studies performed with the EPSRI with senior chemical engineering students, demonstrated that students tend to answer questions on the EPSRI in a more ethical manner than would be expected given their age and education.

The other tool that was developed as part of this NSF IUSE project is a digital game called Contents Under Pressure.  This game was developed in a collaborative effort with educational game developer Filament Games. In Contents Under Pressure, chemical engineering students assume the role of a leader of a small team at a petroleum refinery (refer to Figures 1 and 2). Throughout a narrative that occurs over 15 real-world days, students will make a series of binary decisions in an attempt to balance the plant's productivity (money icon), their personal reputation (person with a star icon), the level of process safety (hard hat icon), and time constraints (clock icon). As the narrative unfolds, students interact with a broad cast of characters representing diverse backgrounds and levels of experience while trying to avoid critical plant failures (newscaster and employee are shown in Figures 1 and 2 respectively). The scenarios presented in Contents Under Pressure reflect real-world scenarios that participants may experience when working in the chemical industry. Contents Under Pressure has been used in senior level classes at multiple universities around the country as a safe and authentic process safety decision-making training tool while serving as a basis for discussion about the impacts of decisions in an engineering environment. Studies related to Contents Under Pressure have shown that students who engage with it are more interested in further learning about process safety.

Creation of both Contents Under Pressure and the EPSRI allowed for comparisons to be made between the two approaches to process safety training. As noted above, when responding to the EPSRI students may be "anticipating the test" - that is, they understand that their decision making is being evaluated, which leads them to respond in ways that may not accurately reflect their age or experience. We were able to observe this directly when comparing student responses within the EPSRI to decisions made in Contents Under Pressure, which presents one of the EPSRI dilemmas in a more immersive context. Used in conjunction, both the EPSRI and Contents Under Pressure provide valuable and interesting insights into the difficulties associated with process safety decision making and can lead to creation of educational approaches that help better prepare engineering students for their careers within the chemical industry.
